rename.from: Regression: Getting "Has no TestFixtures" message executing via nunit3-console.exe
rename.to: Getting "Has no TestFixtures" message executing via nunit3-console.exe

body: Can you provide us with a test case?

Please have a look at [this](https://github.com/Full360Solutions/Saucery/blob/master/Saucery3/GuineaPigTests.cs)

SauceryBase has a [TestFixtureSource(typeof(SomeClass)] attribute. SauceryBase inherits from another class that has the [TestFixture] attribute.

SomeClass inherits from IEnumerable with a public IEnumerator GetEnumerator() method.
This functionality was working correctly in Release 3.0.  This bug has been introduced in Release 3.0.1.  It is critical for me as my product relies on this working.

I just filed two bugs against another open source project regarding problems that impact NUnit. In order to produce workable bugs and get some priority, I spent an hour putting together a simplified test case that stood on it's own and showed the project maintainers what was expected versus what was actually happening. They responded very rapidly.

Can you provide us with a simplified test case that stands on it's own - one we can compile - that shows the problem you are seeing? Without it, someone else will have to be interested enough to take on the bug, create the case, have you confirm that it's correct and then figure out how to fix it. 

Which do you think might be quicker? :-)

Charlie

#715 is the issue that talks about the functionality that was kindly implemented but has become broken in release 3.0.1.  I will check all the commits between Release 3.0.0 and 3.0.1 to see if I can help narrow down where the bug has been introduced. Request is to restore the functionality #715 added.  Associated pull request is https://github.com/nunit/nunit/pull/738

That will work too. I still don't know what exactly you are reporting as broken, but if you find the cause it will probably become clear. :-)

As for the functionality of #715, it's still there. We use it. Our tests test it. What's we don't know is exactly what use case is now breaking for you. Whatever it is, that use case is not in our tests, so the fact that it worked before is basically some sort of happy accident.

If you are able to create a test case, we will include it to prevent future regressions.

Huh... the three dots don't compile.

Just kidding, we can try a do-nothing class with that structure and see what happens.

The use case is simply that if ClassThatInheritsFromIEnumerable returns 10 instances of ClassReturnedByClassThatInheritsFromIEnumerable then 10 \* 2 = 20 tests are executed.

Have just downgraded back to NUnit Release 3.0.0 and it is working...thus proving that this usecase has been broken in release 3.0.1.

So what it is actually doing is not finding any tests, right?

The message about not finding any test fixtures could probably be worded better for this situation.  It usually means that there were no classes with test cases. There may actually be 10 empty test fixtures getting generated. Would you take a look at your XML output to see if that's the case?
It certainly appears that it is not finding any tests.  It generates this message almost immediately and exits out.  No tests are executed.
Nothing in my XML output.  Tests fail immediately.  Can we please take the confirm label off.
Investigating point of failure. It is broken when I upgrade back to release 3.0.1...investigating where exactly by comparing above example with mine

Hmmm,  Well that was a bit screwed.  I've spent all night rebuilding my project from the ground up comparing my version with your example. Gradually add more and more of my original code base to the working example expecting to find the smoking gun....didn't find it.  My new code base is working with NUnit 3.0.1.

Don't know what is wrong with the old version of my codebase.  That's frustrating.

May I request that unit tests are captured and included in the bank of unit tests for this usecase.

I wouldn't want to debug that again!

Thanks
I have a branch that contains the test I sent you, which I can merge. If you have others, I'll add them.
I've been taking a dog fooding system test approach to date.  Less than ideal, I know.  I would love to offer you a bank of unit tests of this use case but i don't have any.

No problem. Thought I'd ask anyway.

On Mon, Dec 14, 2015 at 1:54 PM, Andrew Gray notifications@github.com
wrote:

> I've been taking a dog fooding system test approach to date. Less than
> ideal, I know. I would love to offer you a bank of unit tests of this use
> case but i don't have any.
> 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/nunit/nunit/issues/1118#issuecomment-164571795.
I'm going to close this after adding the test to our codebase.
Thank you.  That's fine.
@CharliePoole where is the branch containing the unit tests you referred to?  I'd like to take look at them.

@agray Thanks for the reminder. I pushed it and created a PR. Please take a look at
   https://github.com/nunit/nunit/pull/1157
